M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to *M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31*, along with applicable Massachusetts family law and case law supporting modification of custody orders to serve the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed in the Bristol Probate and Family Court, which has jurisdiction over matters concerning custody and parenting orders under *M.G.L. c. 215, § 3*.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The above circumstances constitute a material change in conditions since the original custody order and require this Court’s intervention to ensure the minor child’s safety and welfare, consistent with her best interests under *M.G.L. c. 208, § 28.*

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody orders may be modified based on a material and substantial change in circumstances, provided the modification serves the best interests of the child.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion directly cites G.L. c. 208, § 28 and explains that a Probate Court judge may modify an earlier custody judgment upon finding a ‘material and substantial change in the circumstances’ and that the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ The court then applies this standard to the mother’s complaint for modification, affirming that her rehabilitation constituted a material and substantial change but remanding because the best-interests analysis regarding splitting the twins was inadequately supported. This squarely matches the proposition about when custody orders may be modified under Massachusetts law.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ … When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.”

Rollins v. Rollins, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Rollins v. Rollins, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (2002)
Rollins v. Rollins, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody orders may be modified based on a material and substantial change in circumstances, provided the modification serves the best interests of the child.
Rollins v. Rollins, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 90.case_name: Beryl v. Superintendent, Souza-Baranowski Correctional Center
Rollins v. Rollins, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns certiorari review of a prison disciplinary proceeding and the need for the full administrative record (including a videotape) to be before the court. It does not address family law, custody, or modification of custody orders, nor does it discuss material and substantial changes in circumstances or the best interests of the child. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed custody-modification proposition under Massachusetts law.
Rollins v. Rollins, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: In an action in the nature of certiorari, the court’s task is to review the administrative record for substantial errors of law that affect material rights. It follows that for this type of review to take place, all of the evidence considered at the administrative hearing must be placed before the court.

Bezio v. Patenaude, 381 Mass. 563 (1980).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have long prioritized the safety, welfare, and developmental needs of the child when determining custody arrangements.
Bezio v. Patenaude, 381 Mass. 563 (1980).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly situates its analysis within a long line of Massachusetts custody and guardianship cases that emphasize the child’s welfare and best interests as the paramount consideration. It surveys earlier decisions (Duclos, Wilkins, Perkins, Malkin, and others) and concludes that all relevant statutory tests—parental fitness, guardian suitability, and removal—are to be applied with primary reference to the welfare and best interests of the child. This historical discussion supports the proposition that Massachusetts courts have long prioritized children’s safety, welfare, and developmental needs in custody determinations.
Bezio v. Patenaude, 381 Mass. 563 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Wilkins and Duclos suggest that the custody provision of the guardianship statute, G. L. c. 201, § 5, and the guardian removal provision, G. L. c. 201, § 33, are to be read together in an appropriate case… More importantly, both cases stand for the proposition that all factors should be considered with primary reference to the welfare of the child. … To the extent that cases such as the one at bar may be decided with reference to a particular test or standard, we believe that the critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Massachusetts courts have long prioritized the safety, welfare, and developmental needs of the child when determining custody arrangements.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames custody analysis around the impact of domestic violence on the child, directing trial courts to make explicit findings on how such violence affects the child and the appropriateness of custody in light of those effects. The court emphasizes the profound psychological and developmental harm to children who witness or experience domestic violence and ties this directly to the “best interests” custody standard. This confirms that Massachusetts courts prioritize the child’s safety, welfare, and developmental needs when determining custody arrangements.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children. … There are significant reported psychological problems in children who witness domestic violence, especially during important developmental stages. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Courts are empowered to modify custody and parenting arrangements where one parent’s health condition prevents them from safely caring for the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case concerns relocation/removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30 when parents share joint physical and legal custody, and it applies a best-interests-of-the-child analysis. It does not involve or discuss any parent’s health condition or an inability to safely care for the children, nor does it address modifying custody or parenting arrangements on that basis. The authority of the court exercised here is about relocation and best interests, not about parental health impairing caregiving, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Courts are empowered to modify custody and parenting arrangements where one parent’s health condition prevents them from safely caring for the child.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns relocation and a modification of custody following a move, but there is no discussion of any parent’s health condition or incapacity to safely care for the child. The appellate court actually reverses a change in custody because there was no valid material and substantial change in circumstances, and the change was improperly based on relocation alone. Since health-based inability to care for the child plays no role in the reasoning or holding, the case does not support the stated proposition.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements …”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, Massachusetts courts consider factors such as the stability of the child’s environment, the ability of the parents to provide for the child’s safety, and the impact on the child’s emotional well-being.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses what factors must be weighed when determining the child’s best interests in a removal context, including whether the child’s quality of life will be improved, the impact on the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and how moving or not moving will affect the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs. These considerations encompass the stability of the child’s environment, parental ability to provide for needs (including safety), and the child’s emotional well-being. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition about the factors Massachusetts courts consider in best-interests analysis.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, Massachusetts courts consider factors such as the stability of the child’s environment, the ability of the parents to provide for the child’s safety, and the impact on the child’s emotional well-being.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the “best interests of the child” standard and identifies relevant considerations, including the child’s need for stability and continuity, the parents’ ability to provide for the child’s physical safety and welfare, and the impact on the child’s well‑being. The court emphasizes stability of existing arrangements, evaluates each parent’s capacity to meet medical, educational, and daily needs, and considers how different custodial arrangements will affect the child’s relationships with each parent, aligning with the stated proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child... The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge... we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ … the mother is more ‘attuned’ to Kali’s medical, educational, and daily needs…”
